meanings.description: PR stands for Pull Request - which means you are sending all the features you have worked to the remote repository.
Pull Requests are a mechanism for a developer to notify team members that they have completed a feature.
DevOps combines development (Dev) and operations (Ops) to unite people, process, and technology in application planning, development, delivery, and operations.
DevOps enables coordination and collaboration between roles like development, IT operations, quality engineering, and security.
An integrated development environment (IDE) is a software application that helps programmers develop software code efficiently.
IDEs increase programmer productivity by combining common activities of writing software into a single application: editing source code, building executables, and debugging.
UX stands for User Experience, and when we say “User Experience”,  we’re referring to how people interact with a product.
UX focuses on having a deep understanding of users, what they need, what they value, their abilities, and also their limitations.
Continuous integration (CI) is a DevOps software development practice where developers regularly merge their code changes into a central repository.
Serverless is a cloud-native development model that allows developers to build and run applications without having to manage servers.
In the early days of the web, anyone who wanted to build a web application had to own the physical hardware required to run a server, but now this is not necessary thanks to serverless.
Web scraping is an automatic method to obtain large amounts of data from websites.
There are modern tools such as Playwright, Selenium and Puppeteer that can do Web Scrapping.
The Edge is a form of serverless environment without cold starts and minimal runtime that allows code execution geographically close to its end users.

“Edge” is a generalized concept for the boundary of the network. Edge computing is a networking philosophy focused on bringing computing as close to the source of data as possible to reduce latency and bandwidth use.
SSR (Server-Side Rendering), is a pre-rendering technique that involves generating the complete HTML of your web application's pages on each request.

With “Server Side Rendering”, the server is doing some extra work. Instead of just sending back JavaScript to the browser and letting it construct the DOM, you are sending the ready HTML and the necessary JavaScript.
This is a useful technique when you need to frequently update and retrieve new data on a web page. Also, the page becomes easily accessible and indexable, resulting in better SEO.
